page.title: 12VEGETATION AND LAND USE
page.content: The natural vegetation of this area has been greatly altered by human activity.Once forested,this area today has been cleared of trees and the present scattered woodland (both deciduous and coniferous) planted as a crop.Only on Butser Hill is there any climax vegetation - the secondary climax of yew woodland,which is rare as it is poisionous to animals.For many centuries the chalk downland was covered by grass and grazed by sheep; today apart from the steep slopes,the pasture has been ploughed up and the land used for arable crops such as rape,broad beans and wheat.Such intensive farming ('AGRIBUSINESS') has led to the removal of hedgerows, changing the look of the landscape and resulting in new problems such as soil erosion.
